ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped me to develop my critical thinking and writing skills. I felt that the reading responses were especially helpful in making a concise argument. Professor Kunzel is the best seminar leader I have ever taken a class with, hands down.

Insight into a history that is extremely prevalent in modern-day U.S., but often not explicitly addressed. The subject matter discussed in this course provided me with a much stronger understanding of how slavery, racism, and its legacies impact American society, as well as how we might address these realities moving forward.
I feel like my whole worldview has been changed and I understand American history differently because of this class!
An in-depth history of the US incarceration system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - engaging seminar, interesting reading, clear feedback
Weaknesses - too much and/or repetitive reading, slanted views in reading and discussion

Strengths: Subject matter was wide-ranging in both timeframe and geographic location, discussions were engaging and interesting, analyzed a variety of material from different sources and perspectives -- ranging from the scholarly works of people like Foucault who had no personal experience with the carceral system, to art that emerged from within carceral facilities.
Weaknesses: Honestly, none that I can think of.

Strengths:
Continuity
Differences in media as learning tools
Engaging discussions with course material
Professor Kunzel's experience with the material and subject

Weaknesses:
N/A

Strengths: wide range of topics covered, Professor Kunzel is a fantastic moderator and discussion is super substantive and engaging, papers are spaced well in order to generate growth through semester.

Weaknesses: n/a

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Yes! Yes! This is one of the great, if not the greatest, courses I have ever taken here at Yale. You will read a lot and learn a lot, and Professor Kunzel is a really good seminar leader.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. I took this course as a senior, and I would recommend taking this course in a semester that you know you will have the time to give to it. It is a lot of reading, and you will consistently be expected to write responses and engage thoughtfully in seminar. I appreciated the workload in many ways because none of it felt like busy work. Seminars were run excellently by Professor Kunzel, and she added just the right amount of historical information so as to facilitate discussion but not to turn the seminar into a lecture. I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning about incarceration, and I think the class could benefit from a few more contrarian voices.
Yes! An incredibly eye-opening course that truly changed my perspective on the current state of U.S. politics and society, and the way the two interact.
Yes! It is an excellent angle on US history and Prof. Kunzel is fantastic.

I would very much so recommend this course to other students at Yale College. Professor Kunzel has created an incredible course that challenges students to endeavor for greater overall knowledge and understanding in a rather intense and harsh vein of history in the United States. Additionally, the seminar style learning rivaled that of Directed Studies if not exceeded in terms of engagement, material, and progress with writing abilities and prowess.
Yes, it is a top tier history seminar and accessible to non-humanities majors.
